newsitem.title: USA: US threatens EU with WTO action over tallow ban.
newsitem.headline: US threatens EU with WTO action over tallow ban.

text.p: The United States is threatening to take the European Union to the World Trade Organization over a new meat safety directive, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Trade Representatives Office said Thursday.

"We have expressed our concern to the EU concerning the directive," which would prohibit use of certain animal tissues such as tallow, the spokeswoman said. "If they don't change the directive, we'll take them to the WTO."

The new directive, which the EU reportedly plans to implement in January, is aimed at controlling the spread of mad cow disease by banning the parts of cattle most likely to carry the disease from entering the food chain.
But the directive also has major consequences for pharmaceuticals and cosmetics manufacturers, since beef tallow derivatives are used in a wide variety of those products.

The EU directive would have "a severe negative impact" on U.S. exports if it goes into effect, USTR Spokeswoman Kirsten Powers said. She could not confirm a report that it would block as much as $100 million in annual tallow sales to the EU.

"It seems to be a little overzealous on their part considering we don't have BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy--the scientific name for mad cow disease) in this country," said Alisa Harrison, a spokeswoman for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association.
Tallow is a "big byproduct of cattle production" so a trade ban could have major consequences, she said.
Last year, British health officials announced a possible connection between BSE and a similiar human brain disease.
